title: Set up database environment
content:
This topic provides the database administrator required information to configure various types of databases with the Operations Orchestration (OO) Workflow Designer.

Overview

The meaning of the term “database” depends on the database vendor/technology used. In Oracle, the term “database” relates to a collection of files containing data and metadata. A single Oracle database may contain one or more schemas (and users). A Microsoft SQL Server “database” is closer in definition to Oracle’s "schema" than to Oracle’s "database".

To avoid confusion, this topic will use the following terms:

  • Instance/server–the software and memory structures providing Relational Database Management System (RDBMS) services
  • Database–the entity containing tables, views, indexes, and more

Review the following points related to the database usage:

  • OO Workflow Designer requires a single database. This database may coexist with other databases such as IdM database contained in a database server.
  • OO Workflow Designer database connectivity relies on Java JDBC. If your environment requires specific adaptations or security measures, see the JDBC documentation (or database vendor documentation) to learn and use the JDBC connection URL format.
  • This topic also contains information about the types of databases used with OO Workflow Designer and describes the required database settings. If the settings aren't specified you can leave the default values or continue with those configured by your organization's database administrator.

IdM database configuration

You can set up database for IdM service at the time of OO Workflow Designer installation using wizard. For instructions to configure and create IdM and its specific database, see Install OO Workflow Designer topic. 

The current release of on-premises OO Workflow Designer supports only Create IdM Service for authentication.
The Connect IdM Service authentication isn't supported. Therefore, you'll not be able to connect to an external IdM service. 

Language Support

You can install OO Workflow Designer in any supported language (English, French, German, Japanese, Spanish, and Simplified Chinese). Configuration of databases and database servers should be correct to support the desired language.

Use database clusters

Database clusters help to make the OO Workflow Designer system more robust, by protecting the database from several types of failures. OO Workflow Designer doesn't offer database cluster related features of its own, such as database connection failover. It relies on the functionality of the JDBC package used, and the database cluster environment capabilities, such as SCAN/AG listeners. You can install OO Workflow Designer in conjunction with any type of database cluster environment that satisfies the following conditions:

  • Supports connection pooling
  • Accepts a single, valid database URL
  • It provides reliable transaction handling during failover (a single, complete transaction must either completely fail or succeed)

The OO Workflow Designer installer doesn't offer database cluster specific installation options. During installation, enter the simplistic/regular form of the database connection details in the installation wizard. Database URL adaptations are usually done after the system is already installed in the database.properties configuration file.

Database security

The OO Workflow Designer database is at the heart of the OO Workflow Designer system, containing the OO Workflow Designer system configuration and possibly corporate sensitive data. It's highly recommended that you enforce strict security settings on your database by following these guidelines. Harden your database server by following the recommendations from the database vendor and the operating system vendor. Server hardening may include, among other items:

  • Restrict SSH access on Linux servers to a well controlled set of OS users
  • Enforce a strict OS user password policy–password length, complexity, lockout policy, and more
  • Set up an audit system to detect and report break in attempts

Harden your database user/login accounts:

  • Enforce the password policy–password length, complexity, lockout policy, and more
  • Restrict access to administration level accounts
  • Set up an audit system to detect and report break in attempts

You can use the available database encryption at the file system level provided it doesn't compromise OO Workflow Designer's performance and is completely transparent to the application. For example, you can use Oracle Transparent Data Encryption (TDE) as long as it doesn't cause any performance degradation or prevent Large Object (LOB) free space reclamation.

Database specific adaptations

This topic describes several key database specific adaptations and requirements.

  • Microsoft SQL Server: If you are deploying using an SQL Server database, you need to set the following options for the database: 
    Allow Snapshot Isolation : True 
Is Read Committed Snapshot On : True 
Auto Shrink : False 
Auto Create Statistics : True
  • Oracle SQL: If you use an Oracle database, you need to configure the Oracle server PROCESSES and OPEN_CURSORS to guarantee at least 1000 concurrent connections (>=1000) and at least 900 open cursors (>=900) per session.
  • PostgreSQL: If you use the PostgreSQL database, you need to configure the PostgreSQL server configuration file postgresql.conf with the following options: 
    default_transaction_isolation = 'read committed'
autovacuum = on
track_counts = on
max_connections = 1000

Database sizing

OO Workflow Designer keeps all content and configuration data in the database. This topic will help you prepare for installing OO Workflow Designer. By estimating your system scale (small/standard/enterprise), you can decide the following:

  • The amount of disk space required
  • the amount of memory (RAM) used by the database
  • Additional database installation parameters.

You may estimate the system scale using the following table:

System Criteria\Scale Small Standard Enterprise
Number of content packs* 1 to 9 10 to 49 50 or more
Number of users** 1 to 9 10 to 49 50 or more 
* Number of content packs refers to the number of distinct items in the OOST_CONTENT_ITEMS table (and satellite tables).
** Number of users means the number of workspaces, projects, and so on. This is assuming that every user has 10 workspaces.

The following table provides disk space and memory requirements for different OO Workflow Designer deployment scales:

System Scale\Parameter Database Disk Size Requirements Memory
Small 10 GB 4 GB
Standard 50 GB 8 GB
Enterprise Between 50 and 100 GB 12 GB
  • Disk space and memory values are estimates. Actual disk space and memory consumption vary, depending on the database vendor and database server configuration.
  • Memory (RAM) reflects recommended database memory, not the overall amount of memory available on the database machine (virtual or physical server).
  • Disk space reflects the amount of disk space required for the everyday operation of the OO Workflow Designer system and reasonable historical data retention—not including long term database backups.
  • The amount of additional disk space required for keeping OO Workflow Designer database backups depends on the backup policy (frequency and retention period).

Hardware requirements

The following table describes the hardware (CPU and memory) requirements recommended for each of the database servers. The memory values reflect database memory consumption as part of the entire machine’s memory.

Database\Scale Small/Standard Enterprise
CPUs RAM CPUs RAM
Small Standard Min Rec Min Rec Min Rec
SQL Server 2 4 4 GB 8 GB 4 8 GB 4 GB 8 GB
Oracle 2 4 4 GB 8 GB 4 8 GB 4 GB 8 GB
PostgreSQL 2 4 4 GB 8 GB 4 8 GB 4 GB 8 GB

Min = Minimal value, Rec = Recommended value.

In addition to the generalized hardware requirements listed in the earlier topic, refer to the appropriate hardware requirements and software requirements sections per database.
